facts.text: Respondents 1 to 5 were elected as members of Legislative Council of Madhya Pradesh in the elections held in 1972.
Appellant presented an election petition on June 26, 1972 challenging the election.
Appellant did not deposit Rs. 2000 as security for costs as required under s. 117 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 at the time of presenting the election petition.
High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur dismissed the election petition (Election Petition No. 49 of 1972) on September 22, 1972 for failure to deposit the security under s. 117.
Appeal filed under s. 116A of the Representation of the People Act from the High Court order.

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 117 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 is mandatory or directory.
Whether the deposit of Rs. 2000 security is required at the time of presenting the election petition or only during the course of the trial.
Whether the High Court has discretion to reduce the amount of security deposit or dispense with it under s. 117.
Whether an election petition can be dismissed for non-compliance with s. 117 before the trial commences (i.e., before notices are issued to respondents).

petitioner_arguments.text: s. 117 of the Act is only directory and not mandatory; the deposit of Rs. 2000 is only to secure the costs in the course of the trial of the election petition.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 117 Representation of the People Act, 1951; K. Kamaraja Nadar v. Kunju Thevar

petitioner_arguments.text: Dismissal of the petition for non-compliance with s. 117 is a penalty which is not one of the penalties prescribed under s. 118 of the Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 117, s. 118 Representation of the People Act, 1951

petitioner_arguments.text: The trial had not started as notices were not issued to respondents, and trial commences only after notices are issued; relied on repealed s. 85.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: repealed s. 85, s. 86 Representation of the People Act, 1951

petitioner_arguments.text: Prayer for the High Court to reduce the amount of security deposit.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 117(2) Representation of the People Act, 1951

respondent_arguments.text: s. 117 is mandatory; deposit required at time of filing; no provision conferring discretion on High Court to reduce or dispense with security deposit.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 117 Representation of the People Act, 1951

respondent_arguments.text: s. 117(2) empowers High Court to call for further security but not to absolve or reduce initial deposit.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 117(2) Representation of the People Act, 1951

court_reasoning.text: High Court was right in holding s. 117 mandatory; no competence to reduce or dispense with security deposit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 117(2) allows further security but no provision to absolve from initial deposit.

court_reasoning.text: Repealed s. 85 did not permit condonation of non-compliance with s. 117; trial commences only after compliance with mandatory provisions like s. 117.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prior to 1966 amendment, trial by Tribunal only after compliance.

court_reasoning.text: Right to challenge election is statutory under Art. 329(b); strict compliance required, no common law right or equity discretion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Creature of statute, subject to limitations.

court_reasoning.text: K. Kamaraja Nadar distinguished: directory only for specific wording like 'in favour of Secretary', not for making deposit itself.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Essence is furnishing security; no deposit means non-compliance.

court_reasoning.text: Marginal note to s. 86 'Trial of election petitions' does not limit dismissal under s. 86(1) to after notice; language clear.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Non-deposit leaves no option but to reject petition.

holdings.text: s. 117 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 is mandatory; security must be deposited at time of presentation.
High Court has no discretion to reduce or dispense with the security deposit under s. 117.
Election petition must be dismissed for non-compliance with s. 117 even before trial commences or notices issued.
Non-deposit of security under s. 117 leaves no option to the Court but to reject the petition.

precedents_cited.case_name: N. P. Ponnuswami v. Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Right to challenge election is statutory; strict compliance required; no common law right.

precedents_cited.case_name: K. Kamaraja Nadar v. Kunju Thevar and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Held certain wording in unamended s. 117 directory, but essence is furnishing security; does not aid non-deposit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lalaram v. The Supreme Court of India and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Relates to security for review petition under Supreme Court Rules; irrelevant.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: s. 117 mandatory for security deposit at presentation; non-compliance leads to dismissal under s. 86(1); no condonation.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Right to challenge election provided only by statute in manner prescribed.

outcome.summary: The appeal against the Madhya Pradesh High Court's dismissal of the election petition for non-deposit of security under s. 117 is dismissed, upholding that s. 117 is mandatory with no discretion to reduce or dispense.

key_quotes.text: the non-deposit of the security along with the election petition as required under s. 117 of the Act leaves no option to the Court but to reject it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on mandatory nature and consequence of non-compliance.

key_quotes.text: The right conferred being a statutory right, the terms of that statute had to be complied with.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes strict statutory compliance for election challenges under Art. 329(b).

key_quotes.text: What is of the essence of the provision contained in s. 117 is that the petitioner should furnish security for the costs of the petition.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes K. Kamaraja Nadar; deposit itself mandatory.
